column166: Parking Spaces Add'l to Main Unit
column182: Seems to overlay RC and IL base districts (districts surrounding airports and military bases).
column183: Overlay airport zones shall refer to Newport News-Williamsburg International Airport, and military airport shall refer to Camp Peary Field and Langley Air Force Base. The base districts for these include "RC" and "IL"; While IL does not permit any housing, RC allows single family detached by right and duplexes by public hearing. This overlay does not prevent or encourage development in areas already permitted by the base district, and instead seeks to restrict the height of structures and objects of natural growth in the vicinity of any civil or military airport in the county or its environs.

column166: Parking Spaces Add'l to Main Unit
column182: Exact location of overlay uncertain, mentions location along Routes 17, 60 (Bypass Road/Richmond Road) and 143 (Merrimac Trail) which implies this overlays could be both residential and commercial base districts. Only map found (not on zoning map) shows some overlays on route 17 only, covering base district GB (nonresidential), so logging as nonresidential: https://www.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmaps.yorkcounty.gov%2Farcgis%2Frest%2Fservices%2FAGOservices%2FLandrecords_Service%2FFeatureServer%2F10&source=sd
column183: The Commercial Corridor Revitalization Overlay District is established to encourage re-use and redevelopment of physically constrained properties, as defined herein, in a manner that is beneficial for the corridor and economically viable for the property owner. The district is designed to provide additional flexibilities for development and redevelopment situations on such properties with the objective of restoring those properties to an economically viable and attractive component of the commercial corridor.

column182: Online GIS map shows FEMA floodplain zones described and used as guidance for this overlay
column183: The special provisions established in this section shall apply to the areas designated as Special Flood Hazard Areas as determined by the Flood Insurance Study (FIS) and as delineated on the Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) for York County prepared by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Federal Insurance Administration dated January 16, 2015. Permitted uses, specially permitted uses, accessory uses, dimensional standards, and special requirements shall be as established by the underlying zoning district, except as specifically prohibited (manufactured housing). Structures must comply with floodplain construction standards.

column183: The purpose of the historic resources management overlay district is to protect the historic cultural resources of the county by ensuring that historic buildings and archeological sites are acknowledged, properly documented and protected or recovered as development activity occurs.

column183: Residential uses are limited to housing for individuals 62 years old or over (independent living facilities).

column140: Affordable housing incentive provisions: Where a developer proposes the construction of a planned development project, all or a portion of which will consist primarily of detached dwelling units approved by the board in recognition of their potential for price moderation (i.e., below market average prices) such project may be submitted for consideration by the commission and the board in accordance with the following minimum design criteria, notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary set forth elsewhere in the PDR regulations. § 24.1-360 (g).
column166: Parking Spaces Add'l to Main Unit
column183: Unless specifically excepted by the board of supervisors based on a superior design proposal, not more than 25% of the total number of dwelling units shall be single-family detached. Unless specifically excepted by the board of supervisors based on a superior design proposal, at least 40% of the dwelling units shall be located in buildings that have ground-floor, pedestrian-oriented commercial, office or civic space. In order to ensure diversity in the demographic characteristics of the mixed-use project, not more than 20% of the dwelling units may be restricted as senior housing.

column166: Parking Spaces Add'l to Main Unit
column182: The maximum development density for a PDR development shall be generally consistent with the density envisioned by the adopted comprehensive plan for the area in which located. The board may, however, approve density increases as a part of the PDR approval and, in the case of Senior Housing developments, may consider density allowances of up to twenty (20) units per acre.
column183: All development within a PDR shall be served by public water and sewer. Affordable housing is incentivized but not required per section 24.1-361 (g).

column183: The Route 17 corridor overlay district regulations are designed and intended to protect the aesthetic and visual character of the Route 17 corridor leading to the Yorktown historic district. All development proposed within the corridor shall be subject to the procedures and standards set forth in this section in addition to those required by the underlying district regulations. Primarily, this overlay district is intended to provide a positive visual experience for those visitors coming into and through the county along this corridor. The provisions that follow include both requirements (using the word "shall") that must be met and recommendations (using the word "should") that suggest desirable features and treatments that property owners are encouraged to voluntarily incorporate into their building/site designs.

column182: Section (b) outlines how to interpret the location of the overlay as "within 250 feet of arterial rights of way." A full list is found there, and measuring on a map shows some areas within this buffer to be residential, some nonresidential.
column183: The tourist corridor management overlay district regulations are designed and intended to protect the aesthetic and visual character of the transportation corridors leading into and through the designated historic districts of Williamsburg and Yorktown. All development proposed within these corridors shall be subject to procedures and standards in addition to those in the district regulations. Primarily this overlay district is intended to provide a positive visual experience for those visitors coming into and through the county.

column183: Except in the case of property proposed for construction of an individual single-family residential dwelling unit, any development proposal, including the subdivision of land, in WMP areas shall be accompanied by an impact study prepared in accordance with the requirements set forth in subsection (f) below. The Watershed Management and Protection Area Overlay regulations are intended to ensure the protection of watersheds surrounding current or potential public water supply reservoirs.

column166: Parking Spaces Add'l to Main Unit
column182: Actions Requiring Approval by the Historic Yorktown Design Committee: Constructing a new building or structure. Public hearing
column183: The Yorktown Historic District is intended to promote and protect the historical significance, appearance, architectural quality, and general welfare of the Yorktown community through the identification, preservation, and enhancement of landmarks, buildings, structures, and areas which have special historical, cultural, architectural, or archaeological significance as provided by Section 15.22306, Code of Virginia. The Historic District and the accompanying guidelines are drawn with the objective of protecting and improving the village character and ambiance and ensuring its preservation for the benefit of the residents of Yorktown and York County.

column166: Parking Spaces Add'l to Main Unit
column183: The YVA district is intended to: (1) Recognize Yorktown which, because of its national and international significance, its unique development history and the interrelatedness of historic, residential and commercial land uses, warrants the application of a special approach to further development; and (2) Recognize and implement the Yorktown Master Plan as an overall guide to the future redevelopment of Yorktown; and (3) Provide development opportunities for a variety of land uses which will contribute to and complement the unique character and village atmosphere of Yorktown.
